findings:
- Bilateral diffuse pulmonary infiltrates with a predominantly peripheral and lower lobe distribution, appearing as patchy opacities.
- Cardiomegaly with an increased cardiothoracic ratio.
- No evidence of pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
- Normal bony thorax with no visible fractures or lesions.
- Mildly enlarged cardiac silhouette with preserved contour.
- Visible central venous catheter in the right subclavian vein.
- Mildly displaced trachea midline.
- No visible mediastinal shift.
- Normal diaphragm contour with no elevation.
- No evidence of consolidation or focal mass lesions.
- Normal pulmonary vasculature with no evidence of pulmonary hypertension.
impression:
- Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates suggestive of interstitial or alveolar process, such as pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or interstitial lung disease.
- Cardiomegaly with possible underlying cardiac pathology or volume overload.
- No acute pleural or pneumothorax process.
- No evidence of focal lung pathology or malignancy.
- Patient likely requires further clinical correlation and possibly CT chest for definitive diagnosis.
full_response:
Findings: - Bilateral diffuse pulmonary infiltrates with a predominantly peripheral and lower lobe distribution, appearing as patchy opacities.
- Cardiomegaly with an increased cardiothoracic ratio.
- No evidence of pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
- Normal bony thorax with no visible fractures or lesions.
- Mildly enlarged cardiac silhouette with preserved contour.
- Visible central venous catheter in the right subclavian vein.
- Mildly displaced trachea midline.
- No visible mediastinal shift.
- Normal diaphragm contour with no elevation.
- No evidence of consolidation or focal mass lesions.
- Normal pulmonary vasculature with no evidence of pulmonary hypertension.
Impression: - Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates suggestive of interstitial or alveolar process, such as pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or interstitial lung disease.
- Cardiomegaly with possible underlying cardiac pathology or volume overload.
- No acute pleural or pneumothorax process.
- No evidence of focal lung pathology or malignancy.
- Patient likely requires further clinical correlation and possibly CT chest for definitive diagnosis.
